data.title: 100+ Czech cat names + their meanings
data.meta_description: Step into the charming realm of Czech cat names! Immerse your cat in the beauty of this Central European culture, choosing from a delightful array inspired by cities, culinary delights, and renowned Czech figures. Find the ideal name that resonates with both your feline companion and yourself.
data.text:
The Czech Republic radiates beauty year-round, yet winter metamorphoses the country into a captivating wonderland. Medieval towns, enchanting cobblestone streets, remarkable museums, myriad churches, grand castles, and lush greenery weave a tapestry of allure. It’s no surprise that many designate the Czech Republic as their favored destination. If you share this sentiment, you might contemplate naming your new cat after facets of Czech culture—be it cities, traditional foods, famous Czech personalities, and beyond.

100+ Czech cat names and their meanings

Cat names inspired by Czech cities, towns, and villages

Breclav: Located in the wine-rich region of South Moravia, Breclav is a gateway to vineyard landscapes and cultural events, with a historical town center reflecting its past.

Brno: Nestled in the heart of Moravia, Brno is a vibrant city known for its rich history, stunning architecture, and lively cultural scene.

Bruntal: Tucked away in the Jeseniky Mountains, Bruntal is a charming town offering outdoor adventures, historic architecture, and the picturesque Sovinec Castle.

Decin: Located in the northern part of the Czech Republic, Decin is a gateway to the Bohemian Switzerland National Park, offering breathtaking landscapes and hiking trails.

Havirov: In the heart of the Silesian region, Havirov is a dynamic city known for its industrial heritage, green spaces, and a diverse range of cultural events.

Jihlava: Located in the Vysocina Region, Jihlava is a historic city with a well-preserved medieval center, Renaissance fountains, and the imposing St. Ignatius Church.

Kladno: A former industrial hub near Prague, Kladno has reinvented itself as a cultural center with theaters, museums, and a lively nightlife scene.

Kolin: A historic town along the Elbe River, Kolin boasts a beautifully preserved Old Town, with landmarks such as the Baroque Church of St. Bartholomew.

Liberec: Surrounded by the Jizera Mountains, Liberec is a winter sports paradise with its ski resorts, as well as home to the striking Ještěd Tower.

Most: A city in the Usti nad Labem Region, Most is known for its coal-mining history, unique suspension bridge, and the artificial lake of Most.

Nachod: A town near the Polish border, Nachod is a gateway to the Adrspach:Teplice Rocks, a stunning natural wonder featuring unique rock formations.

Olomouc: Steeped in history, Olomouc boasts impressive baroque architecture, including the Holy Trinity Column, and is renowned for its UNESCO-listed historical center.

Ostrava: Situated in the industrial region of Moravia-Silesia, Ostrava is a vibrant city known for its coal-mining history, steel industry, and modern cultural scene.

Pardubice: Famous for its gingerbread and horseracing events, Pardubice is a delightful city in East Bohemia with a rich culinary tradition and a passion for equestrian sports.

Plzen: Known as the birthplace of Pilsner beer, Plzen offers beer enthusiasts the chance to explore historic breweries and beer cellars in this western Bohemian city.

Prague: The capital city of the Czech Republic, Prague is a magical metropolis boasting a fairy-tale-like Old Town, iconic Charles Bridge, and the impressive Prague Castle.

Prerov: With a mix of historic landmarks and modern amenities, Prerov is a bustling city in Moravia, where visitors can explore the local markets and enjoy a lively atmosphere.

Pribram: Nestled in the hilly landscapes of Central Bohemia, Pribram is known for its mining history, with a visit to the Hluboka Mine providing insight into the region’s industrial past.

Prostejov: A center of fashion and industry, Prostejov in Moravia is renowned for its textile production and offers a blend of historic charm and contemporary commerce.

Sumperk: Surrounded by the Jeseniky Mountains, Sumperk is a haven for nature lovers, offering hiking and skiing opportunities along with a quaint town center.

Tabor: A medieval gem in South Bohemia, Tabor is famous for its well-preserved city walls, historic Hussite roots, and the picturesque Jordan Pond.

Teplice: Known for its thermal springs, Teplice is a spa town in North Bohemia where visitors can relax and rejuvenate in the healing waters, surrounded by elegant architecture.

Trutnov: Nestled in the foothills of the Krkonose Mountains, Trutnov is a gateway to outdoor adventures, offering hiking, skiing, and a lively music scene.

Vsetin: Set against the backdrop of the Beskid Mountains, Vsetin is a town that seamlessly blends tradition and innovation, offering a glimpse into Moravian culture.

Zatec: Located in the heart of hop-growing country, Zatec is a town in North Bohemia celebrated for its role in brewing and its annual hops festival, attracting beer enthusiasts from far and wide.

Zlin: A city with a strong architectural identity shaped by the renowned modernist architect Tomas Bata, Zlin is a hub of design and innovation in Moravia.

Znojmo: Known for its wine production and medieval charm, Znojmo is a South Moravian town where visitors can explore vineyards, historic cellars, and the impressive Znojmo Castle.

Cat names inspired by traditional Czech foods and drinks

Becherovka: A well-known Czech herbal liqueur, Becherovka is crafted with a secret blend of spices, offering a unique and aromatic taste often enjoyed as a digestif or in cocktails.

Bramborak: A beloved Czech potato pancake, bramborak is a crispy delight made from grated potatoes mixed with onions, garlic, and marjoram, pan-fried to golden perfection.

Cesnecka: Perfect for garlic enthusiasts, cesnecka is a hearty garlic soup, often enjoyed as a warming comfort food during chilly Czech winters.

Chlebicky: Chlebicky are open-faced sandwiches, adorned with various toppings like egg salad, ham, pickles, and spreads.

Cibulacka: Hailing from Moravia, cibulacka is an onion soup, rich and flavorful, often enhanced with beer and served with crispy bread or croutons.

Gulas: A Czech classic, gulas or goulash is a savory stew of slow-cooked meat, typically beef, flavored with paprika, onions, and other spices, offering a rich and satisfying taste.

Houbovka: The earthy richness of mushroom soup, a staple in Czech cuisine, offers a comforting and familiar taste.

Jitrnice: A traditional Czech blood sausage, jitrnice is made with pork, barley, and blood, seasoned with marjoram and other spices, providing a hearty and flavorful experience.

Klobasa: Robust and savory flavors characterize Klobasa, a Czech sausage adding a distinctive taste to any meal.

Knedliky: A staple in Czech cuisine, Knedliky dumplings come in various forms—bread or potato-based—serving as the perfect side to soak up sauces from hearty stews or meats.

Kolace: A delightful pastry, kolace features sweet dough filled with fruit preserves, poppy seeds, or sweetened cheese, making it a popular Czech treat.

Kulajda: A creamy mushroom soup, kulajda is a comfort dish enriched with potatoes, dill, vinegar, and a poached egg, creating a unique blend of flavors.

Lecso: Influenced by Hungarian cuisine, lecso is a pepper and tomato stew often accompanied by eggs, sausage, or bacon, offering a burst of colors and flavors.

Medovnik: A showstopper among Czech desserts, medovnik is a layered honey cake, filled with cream or caramel, and topped with nuts or chocolate, creating a sweet symphony.

Palačinky: Czech pancakes, or palačinky, are thin and delicate, filled with jam, fruit, or cream, making them a versatile and popular dessert or breakfast option.

Ryba: The diversity of Czech fish dishes comes to life in Ryba, a simple yet flavorful culinary experience.

Svičkova: A classic Czech dish, svickova features marinated sirloin served with a creamy sauce made from root vegetables, often accompanied by dumplings.

Sýr: The simplicity of Sýr showcases a diverse array of Czech cheeses, each with its unique taste and texture.

Tatarak: A Czech version of steak tartare, tatarak consists of finely minced raw meat, typically beef, seasoned with spices, onions, and served with bread or toast.

Trdelnik: A sweet pastry delight, trdelnik is a rolled pastry grilled and coated in sugar and cinnamon, often enjoyed as a warm street food treat.

Utopenec: Translated as “drowned man,” utopenec is a pickled sausage, often immersed in a flavorful brine with onions and spices, offering a zesty and savory snack.

Uzenina: Uzenina, a variety of Czech cold cuts, introduces you to the rich and savory world of cured meats, offering a selection of flavorful delights that enhance any meal.

Vanocka: A festive bread, vanocka is a braided, sweet dough filled with nuts and dried fruits, making it a centerpiece of Czech Christmas celebrations.

Zeli: Zeli, a dish featuring the beloved Czech ingredient—cabbage, brings warmth and comfort to your table, embodying the heartiness and simplicity found in Czech home-cooked meals.

Zelnacka: A comforting cabbage soup, zelnacka features sauerkraut, potatoes, and smoked meat, creating a hearty and flavorful dish, especially popular in winter.

Czech cat names inspired by animals

Andulka: Finch

Brouk: Beetle

Čáp: Stork

Delfín: Dolphin

Had: Snake

Holub: Pigeon

Jezevcík: Hedgehog

Kočka: Cat

Kočura: Tomcat

Kohout: Rooster

Kůň: Horse

Krokodýl: Crocodile

Kuna: Mink

Kunec: Rabbit

Kůň: Horse

Koza: Goat

Květák: Bumblebee

Lachtan: Seal

Lev: Lion

Liška: Fox

Medvěd: Bear

Myš: Mouse

Nosorožec: Rhinoceros

Pavouk: Spider

Pes: Dog

Pták: Bird

Ryba: Fish

Slon: Elephant

Male cat names inspired by famous Czech people

Alfréd Radok: A trailblazing figure in the world of theater, Alfréd Radok gained renown as a Czech theater director celebrated for his groundbreaking and innovative approach to stage productions, leaving an indelible mark on the theatrical landscape.

Antonín Dvorák: Celebrated composer, famous for his symphonies and the opera “Rusalka.”

Bohumil Hrabal: Acclaimed author, best known for his novel Closely Watched Trains (Ostře sledované vlaky).

Emil Zátopek: Legendary long-distance runner, winner of four Olympic gold medals, and known for his extraordinary achievements in the marathon.

Franz Kafka: Iconic writer, renowned for his influential works such as The Metamorphosis (Die Verwandlung) and The Trial (Der Process).

Jaroslav Hašek: Author of the satirical masterpiece The Good Soldier Švejk (Osudy dobrého vojáka Švejka za světové války).

Jaromír Jágr: Ice hockey legend, one of the greatest players in the history of the sport, with a remarkable career spanning several decades.

Jan Hus: Religious reformer and philosopher, a key figure in the Bohemian Reformation.

Jan Palach: Student activist, known for self-immolation as a protest against the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1969.

Jan Saudek: Renowned photographer, famous for his provocative and surreal images capturing the human form.

Jan Werich: Versatile artist, known for his contributions to literature, acting, and his collaboration with Jiří Voskovec in the Liberated Theater.

Jiří Menzel: Film director, Oscar-winning for Closely Watched Trains (Ostře sledované vlaky).

Jiří Trnka: Pioneering animator and filmmaker, regarded as the “Father of Czech Animation.”

Josef Čapek: Painter, writer, and poet, associated with the Czech Cubist movement.

Juraj Herz: Juraj Herz was a Czechoslovak and later Czech film director, actor, and screenwriter. He is best known for his work in the horror and fantasy genres. Some of his notable films include The Cremator (Spalovač mrtvol), Ferat Vampire (Upír z Feratu), and Morgiana.

Karel Čapek: Renowned writer, playwright, and science fiction author, famous for the play “R.U.R.” and coining the term “robot.”

Karel Gott: Internationally acclaimed pop singer, known as the “Golden Voice of Prague.”

Karel Zeman: Filmmaker and animator, a pioneer in combining live-action with animation in films like The Fabulous World of Jules Verne.

Miloš Forman: Oscar-winning film director, known for classics like One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest and Amadeus.

Petr Čech: Legendary football goalkeeper, known for his successful career with Chelsea and the Czech national team.

Radek Štěpánek: Former professional tennis player, reaching a career-high ATP singles ranking of World No. 8.

Rainer Maria Rilke: Bohemian-Austrian poet and novelist, celebrated for his lyrically intense works like Letters to a Young Poet (Briefe an einen jungen Dichter).

Rudolf II: Holy Roman Emperor, a patron of the arts and sciences during the Renaissance.

Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk: First President of Czechoslovakia, a philosopher, and a key figure in the country’s establishment.

Tomáš Rosický: Former professional footballer, known for his skill and leadership, notably with Arsenal and the Czech national team.

Václav Havel: Playwright, dissident, and the last president of Czechoslovakia and the first president of the Czech Republic.

Vladimir Remek: Astronaut, the first Czechoslovak in space.

Vladimir Franz: Composer, painter, and politician, known for his distinctive appearance and contributions to various artistic fields.

Zdeněk Miler: Animator, creator of the beloved character “Krtek” (The Little Mole) in children’s animations.

Zdeněk Svěrák: Actor, screenwriter, and playwright, known for his collaboration with Jan Svěrák on the film Kolya (Kolja).

Female cat names inspired by famous Czech people

Adéla Gondíková: Acclaimed actress known for her roles in Czech films and television series, including The Little Mermaid (Malá mořská víla) and An Ambiguous Report About the End of the World (Nejasná zpráva o konci světa).

Alena Šeredová: Model and actress, former partner of Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon.

Anna Geislerová: A highly regarded Czech actress, notable for her performances in films such as Something Like Happiness (Štěstí), Zelary, and The Elementary School (Obecná škola).

Barbora Špotáková: Olympic gold medalist and world record holder in javelin throwing.

Božena Němcová: Renowned 19th-century writer, best known for her novel The Grandmother (Babička).

Dagmar Havlová: Actress and the first wife of President Václav Havel, known for her contributions to Czech theater.

Denisa Allertová: Professional tennis player, known for her achievements on the WTA Tour.

Dorota Nvotová: Actress and singer, recognized for her performances in Czech and Slovak films.

Ema Destinnová: Legendary opera singer, considered one of the greatest sopranos of her time.

Eva Jiřičná: Architect, known for her innovative and influential work in the field of design and architecture.

Gabriela Koukalová: Olympic gold medalist and World Champion in biathlon.

Hana Hegerová: Iconic singer and actress, a prominent figure in Czech music and film.

Hana Mašková: Former professional tennis player, reaching a career-high singles ranking of World No. 27.

Hana Zagorová: Popular singer and actress, known for her contributions to Czech pop music.

Ivana Trump: Former fashion model and businesswoman, first wife of Donald Trump.

Ivana Zemanová: First Lady of the Czech Republic, wife of President Miloš Zeman.

Jana Novotná: Former professional tennis player, Wimbledon singles champion.

Jitka Molavcová: Actress, known for her roles in Czech films and television series.

Karolína Plíšková: Professional tennis player, former World No. 1 in women’s singles.

Kateřina Neumannová: Olympic gold medalist and World Champion in cross-country skiing.

Lída Baarová: Actress, known for her career in Czech and German cinema during the 1930s and 1940s.

Magdaléna Jetelová: Contemporary artist known for her large-scale environmental installations.

Markéta Irglová: Singer-songwriter and actress, won an Academy Award for the song “Falling Slowly” from the film Once.

Martina Sáblíková: Speed skater, multiple Olympic gold medalist and World Champion.

Milada Horáková: Politician and human rights advocate, executed by the Communist regime in 1950.

Nelly Gaierová: Acclaimed ballet dancer, known for her performances with the Czech National Ballet.

Olga Havlová: Human rights activist, the first wife of President Václav Havel.

Renáta Kellnerová: Philanthropist and businesswoman, co-founder of the Kellner Family Foundation.

Simona de Silvestro: Professional racing driver, the first woman to score points in the Formula E Championship.

Šárka Strachová: Alpine skier, Olympic gold medalist and World Champion in slalom skiing.

Conclusion

Did you find inspiration in this list of more than 100 Czech cat names? Let me know in the comments which name you’ve chosen for your new feline friend.
